messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:33): argh. I totally forgot about document.write() when pondering by proxy idea
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:41): Is Content-MD5
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:41): a dead letter of the HTTP spec
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:41): or actually used?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (13:48): bursts out laughing
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (13:48): "It was merely a scan of a sample of seven billion pages, not a scan of the entire Web, which would be prohibitively expensive."
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:50): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/ uses Content-MD5
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (13:50): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: 11 out of a sample of 142236 pages
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:51): (That (plus subpages) are the only ones I can see)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (13:51): <http://www.united-reit.co.jp/> is the only other I found
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (13:51): (admittedly, I have a database which I can query this stuff out of, unlike ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:52): I have 'grep', which works just as well
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:52): but does any UA actually do anything with the info, and are the MD5 sums they send accurate?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (13:52): doesn't have that data
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (13:53): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: how quick is that on the 100MB file?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:54): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: It takes about 0.08 seconds
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (13:55): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: real time or CPU time?

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (13:56): real 0m0.141s/user 0m0.002s/sys 0m0.004s for the query of the database (but, admittedly, it has the advantage of being able to do far more complex queries than grep can)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (13:56): yeah, that's far more expensive :P
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:56): I can cope with waiting 0.08 seconds for a response
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:57): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: so if I wrote a filtering proxy for testing, MD5 wouldn't matter
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (13:57): I really just need something that I can have as part of a browse-able UI, and using grep there would get horrid
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:57): sent mail to implementors@
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:02): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: From a random sample of one page, the MD5 is wrong
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:03): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: thanks
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:04): (no idea how representative that is, but it suggests that nothing checks it)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:05): yeah. I already feel safer with cryptographic hashes protecting me against faulty proxies...
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:06): :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:08): is looking through old photos and thought he'd worked out they were in Portugal, but there's French writing in it. Hmm.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:09): And now it looks like Germany. This makes no sense. They are all within a week of each other.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:11): :-( looks like the typo/grammar quality of my emails gets worse and worse when I write more and more email

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:11): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, are you sure about that? According to RFC2616, the field value isn't merely an ASCII representation of the MD5 sum, it's a base64 encoded string from the binary representation
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:11): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: yeah
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:11): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: peh! base64 is an ASCII representation! :P
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:12): yeah, but you know what I mean
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:13): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Yeah, I know. I'm just being the typical asshole I am :P
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:17): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: From my sample of one page, the MD5 is correct
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:17): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Then we chose a different page, seeming we have the same data set :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:17): s/one/two/
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:18): http://www.united-reit.co.jp/ and http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/ both give the right content-md5
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:18): (when calculating the 'correct' value with GET http://www.united-reit.co.jp/|perl -e'use Digest::MD5 "md5_base64"; print md5_base64 do { local $/; <> }' )
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:21): realises he was using a _different_ base64 than the RFC 1764 (or whichever it is)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:22): should I expect to be able to replace tagName getter via Node.prototype.__defineGetter__ ?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:23): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Not in browsers that don't support __defineGetter__
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:23): moreover, how does one call the native getter from the monkey patch getter?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:23): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: which ones do?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:23): I think it's FF and Opera 9.5, or something like that
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:24): (Not at all sure about WebKit)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:25): hmm. I wonder why my mac doesn't include the base64 command
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:25): but it has the man page for it
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:25): Oh, it looks (from the source code) like WebKit does do __defineGetter__

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:28): "With Firefox 3.0, defining getter or setter on an already-defined property will throw an exception. The property has to be deleted beforehand, what is not the case for older versions of Firefox."
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:29): hmm. so how does one merely *wrap* a native getter or setter and still call the native one as part of the wrapper impl?
